Haywood was born in 1869 in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. His father, a [[Pony Express]] rider, died of pnemonia when Haywood was three years old (Linder 1998). ==Experience in the WFM==
==Experience in the WFM==
â
In 1896, [[Ed Boyce]], president of the [[Western Federation of Miners]], spoke at the [[Idaho]] silver mine where Haywood was working (Linder 1998). Inspired by his speech, Haywood signed up as a WFM member, thus formally beginning his involvement in America's labor movement.
+

â
Haywood immediately became active in the WFM, and by 1900 he had become a member of the national union's General Executive Board. In 1902, he assumed co-leadership of the WFM with [[Charles Moyer]]. That year, the WFM became involved in the [[Colorodo Labor Wars]], a struggle that latest for several years and took the lives of 33 union and non-union workers(Linder 1998). The WFM initiated a series of strikes to combat the brutal working conditions and starvation wages. Haywood began the convention with the following speech:{{ref|zinn2}}
:''Fellow Workers, this is the Continental Congress of the working-class. Despite Haywood's involvement in the IWW, which was heavily influenced by [[anarcho-syndicalism]], he was a longtime member of the [[Socialist Party of America]], and often pleaded with workers to vote in elections.
